content:
0, 2016
												I wish I had looked up some more about this game before I bought it. People say this one is the weakest in the series, and though I haven't played the others, Clear Sky didn't really intice me to do so. I just beat it, and I must say, the whole game was mediocre at it's best, annoying at it's worst. It's buggy, and even when it's not buggy the bullet sponge enemies (and player character) just make it a bit irritating. It's not that hard, I played through the whole game with the starting armor, and if you ever worry you're getting low on money, medical supplies, or ammo, fret not, for the endless supply of military soldiers in Cordon will practically hand over as much of all of the above as you need. The only difficulty in the game stemmed from the necessity to put 1-2 whole extended mags of armor piercing rounds into snorks before they died, yet they could kill you with a couple kicks. Still, even that problem is easily solved with a SPAS.When its not bullet sponges and bugs that are annoying you, its invisible walls that are blocking an area that is totally physically accessable in appearance. Mods like SRP (Sky Reclamation Project) include a lot of bug fixes, and I'm to understand that there are mods to remove invisible walls (I didn't bother to try any mods whatsoever); however, the vanilla game was still a disappointment, though, at times, not entirely unenjoyable.The concept is interesting, but the execution was sub par, at least for this entry in the series. I can't suggest it.

content:
, 2016
												the worst out of the three stalkers by far. honestly not even worth modding and playing a second time but if thats your kind of thing go for it.every single enemy is the video game adaptation of the guy from the navy seal copypasta. no matter where you're hiding or how far away you are from them they will scope you out and pop you in the head like its nothing. they also have an absurd amount of merc-seeking grenades on hand at any given time that are always cooked to perfection so you have little to no time to get out of the way before you're bloodsucker chow. not to mention they all like to throw them at the same time so enjoy having 5-6 grenades directly at your feet at least twice during a firefight.theres also the faction mechanic, funnily enough absent from CoP but its easy to see why. the whole system was half ♥♥♥♥♥ and only relevant in the first hour or two of the game. after that you can pretty much ignore it since it doesnt really affect anything. it would have been a great free-play mechanic but clear sky lacks that entirely.also the story is bad, like really REALLY bad. what starts out as a simple "go find strelok and stop him from getting to the center of the zone ok" turns into a long convoluted fetch quest that can be boiled down to "person A has details on where strelok could be but wont tell you until you do a task, then person A will tell you to go to person B and person B will have you do an exceedingly ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t task to then tell you to go to person C who does the same exact thing until you finally have a romp through limansk which might as well be you running naked through a football field while a bunch of russian dudes hopped up on cocaine shoot at you from all angles."it ain't worth playing. its a prequel to ShoC and really adds nothing to the series as a whole. you could just straight up ignore this game and play ShoC and CoP and you'd get just a good experience as any.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
, 2016
												Disappointing compared to SoC. The upgrade system is a cool idea, but is implemented oddly. Your weapons flat out suck until you invest thousands of rubles in upgrades. You won't be able to headshot an enemy standing twenty yards away with many stock weapons. The pistols and shotguns you start out with seem to shoot weaponized cotton candy bullets.There's no more magic to exploring and getting ambushed by an unseen enemy. As part of the faction wars system, pretty much every enemy shows up on the map, even mutants. Faction wars itself is a huge disappointment. It's a cool idea implemented horribly. Forget Duty and Freedom, it seems that every faction is out for turf! They even turned Loners into a faction. Loners are not a faction, they're the absence of a faction! Beyond the lore issues, there's also gameplay issues.I'll capture an outpost and use a bunch of ammo because my stock AR has like a three foot spread at twenty meters. The enemy faction will then constantly send squads to take back that position. Naturally, the men defending it get whittled away, and I'm likely in no position to help. I was taking over the main bandit base in Garbage, only to have all my work be for nothing because bandits captured the southwest entrance for the billionth time. It's a huge test of patience.Did I mention the grenade spam? Because there's tons of it. Enemies throw a lot of grenades and have amazing accuracy with them. It reaches CoD: WaW levels of stupid with its grenade spam.The story is nothing special. I looked it up out of frustration with the game. The most important thing it does is explain why Strelok ended up brainwashed at the start of ShOC, which I didn't care much about. The Clear Sky faction doesn't matter much in the larger lore.At least I got this game in a sale. The way I look at it, I got Call of Pripyat for 50% off and Clear Sky for free. Speaking of which, I'm moving on to Call of Pripyat now, supposedly the series' magnum opus. Hopefully it's better than this.

content:
er 30, 2016
												I don't know if STALKERs are ever a good game, but after SoC (which I sort of liked apart the sick difficulty and a nasty bug which gave me wrong ending) I didn't learn anything and I made the mistake of starting Clear Sky too with the hardest difficulty and after about half game it's just so hard it isn't fun at all. Pretty much only headshots kill enemies and you will be killed by one headshot too. Even more annoying is that enemies will spot you crouching 100 meters away and instantly kill you alot of times, but if you just run around pointlessly they hardly ever hit you. If you play vanilla game even the latest version is quite buggy.Luckily you can just skip lot of the useless gang war part, but that's pretty much only thing you can grind money with. If you upgrade your first scoped rifle a bit you can end the game with it. Anomalies are very hard to find and you don't get to keep any anomalies from quests so it's all extra work. I don't know if it's the difficulty or some patch, but in youtube most people finish the game shooting through a fence and in my version that doesn't do any damage so I think I loaded the game about 200 times to finish the final battle. And someone said there's about 1 hour of the game left at one stage and I'm quite sure it took me about 12 hours to finish after that, because it's just save after killing every enemy or get killed and reload all the time.Also the storyline in the game is weak. Maybe at 1 or 2 points there's a wow effect because of SoC, but other than that it's just boring.

content:
ber 25, 2016
												Being a fan of the other 2 games in the series I bought this one expecting another great FPS but what a steaming pile of crap I stepped in. I could only get through about 6 hours of playing it before I felt like I was totally wasting my time. The combat is probably the worst I've ever experienced. I've tried a variety of weapons, upgraded damage and accuracy on some, and still the enemies just seem unaffected by me unloading all my ammo into them while they kill me with ease. The armor they start you with is totally worthless as are the guns. I thought I just needed to explore a little to get better equipment and upgrade things but even that didn't help. Because the combat system is totally broken that makes it near impossible to accomplish anything since most of the quests are about attacking or defending something which is hard to do when your equipment is totally ineffective. To make it worse, the trade system sucks too. Find a gun worth 1000? You'll probably be able to sell it for 50. Good luck saving up to mod your weapons and armor at that rate. Then again, the upgrades don't help so why bother.With the combat and trade systems being total garbage, I just don't see any reason to continue playing this game. There are much better games out there that are more worthwhile. I've heard certain aspects of the game can be fixed with mods but you know what works better than hunting down mods to fix a crappy game? Installing a better game that works right from the start. Skip this one and spend your money elsewhere.

content:
y 8, 2012
												The best version of a fantastic open world wasteland franchise. Like the Metro series, STALKER is a post-apoctolypic semi-mysitcal (Russians seem to like having paranormal elements in thier scifi) Russian game. However, while the Metro series is linear (yet finds room for female characters) STALKER is almost totally open (yet almost totally empty of women). Also unlike Metro, STALKER tends to run fairly well on my machine.Clear Sky is an enhancement of the STALKER formula. Several addtions are present, not the least of which are gun mods (your favorite weapons can be useful forever now, instead of quickly replaced whenever a new gun appears) and a more interesting story. If your like me and Fallout never really did it for you, give this game a shot.

content:
r 20, 2015
												I've played S.T.A.L.K.E.R. Clear Sky just after discovering Shadow of Tchernobyl.Except some improvements in the rendering engine (mostly lighting) and the interface (HUD and Inventory), the gameplay is mostly the same, so you won't be lost in this new opus.The most important element of gameplay provided here is the Mechanic guy, who can repair and upgrade your equipment (armor, weapons). Being able to customize your gear early really add to the game.In spite of this, I encountered a huge difficulty wall after cleaning the "swamp". After emerging from a huge pipe, I'm confronted with about 20 soldiers and a huge machinegun. This was a halt for me and I never succeeded in exploring what the game had to offer.I didn't like it because I played leisurely in easy mode (that was hard enough for me). I would have accepted it after like 4 to 5h of play, like in Shadow of Tchernobyl, when you emerge inside the soldier camp !So in spite of its qualities, I really cannot recommend this game who doesn't want to be played even in easy mode.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 7, 2015
												Maybe the game just isn't for me but here are some of the reasons why I dislike it.Weapons and ammo are named for people who like guns in real life rather than being named so that gamers can easily identify what is what at a seconds glance. The bleeding mechanic is annoying. You get bleeding for pretty much any hit so you better scavenge any and all healing items (apart from food which is just going to weigh you down) you come across.Your weapons rarely feel like they have an "impact" on enemies. You can hit an enemy 8 times with a weapon and they barely look like they are harmed by it. There is no limping, no slowing down of movements, no trying to escape when their life is too low, no stumble when hit by a heavy impact weapon like a shotgun. The only times it feels like your weapons have an impact is when you hit an enemy in the head at which point they're instakilled.Combat in general is tedious. You have to attack multiple enemies and they all take so many bullets (unless you manage to get good headshots (which isn't easy with how inaccurate weapons are)) to go down while you only need to take a handful to die. You end up playing pop a mole from cover most of the time and there is rarely any other tactic to use since if you kill an enemy pretty much all other enemies are alerted to your presence so sneaking is out of the question. And maybe it is just because I never found a good long range weapon but sniping wasn't viable for me. Neither was storming the place either. It's pretty much just pop a mole from cover for the most part.The dialogue in the game is "topic dialogue". Meaning that your character asks questions and the NPC's spew out paragraphs of exposition. I don't care for this kind of dialogue as characters just end up being meat shield/walking lore pamphlets.I'm not well versed with this regions names, culture and dialects so for me every character blended together with one another. Pretty much no one stood out so I ended up not caring about any of them.On that note, I don't even care about the main character. From what I saw during my playtime you are some random ♥♥♥♥ with amnesia or whatever who can survive strange emissions but they will gradually harm you until you die so you need to go to the center of the zone in order to find answers. However, since the character you play as has pretty much no personality or backstory or even motive to go into the zone (from what I understand the outside world isn't completely ♥♥♥♥ed up so why couldn't "Scar" just leave if the emissions are so harmful in the zone?) I don't care about him. I don't care about wanting to solve this mystery because the game gives me ♥♥♥♥ all of an incentive to solve it. I just don't care.Anyway, whenever I play a game for a while to get a good feel for it I sit down and think about the game as to why I'm playing it and why I should continue. So is the game challenging? Well, no. It is at first, but once you figure out how the mechanics work it stops being challenging and just grows frustrating or tedious. Does the game have an amazing story? Not really, as I explained above. Is the game at least a fun time consumer to just waste time in? Not really. The gameworld is pretty barren for the most part and all you find is anomolies and enemies which quickly get repetitive and boring.Does it at least have an amazing atmosphere to immerse into? Not really. It doesn't feel dark or dreary or anything really. It feels cartoonish if anything.Like I said, it might just not be the kind of game for me but I can't see any reason to keep playing it. The story never grabbed me, the characters blend together, the world is barren (apart from enemies), the combat gets repetitive and tedious and the atmosphere is lacking.

However, since the character you play as has pretty much no personality or backstory or even motive to go into the zone (from what I understand the outside world isn't completely ♥♥♥♥ed up so why couldn't "Scar" just leave if the emissions are so harmful in the zone?) I don't care about him. I don't care about wanting to solve this mystery because the game gives me ♥♥♥♥ all of an incentive to solve it. I just don't care.Anyway, whenever I play a game for a while to get a good feel for it I sit down and think about the game as to why I'm playing it and why I should continue. So is the game challenging? Well, no. It is at first, but once you figure out how the mechanics work it stops being challenging and just grows frustrating or tedious. Does the game have an amazing story? Not really, as I explained above. Is the game at least a fun time consumer to just waste time in? Not really. The gameworld is pretty barren for the most part and all you find is anomolies and enemies which quickly get repetitive and boring.Does it at least have an amazing atmosphere to immerse into? Not really. It doesn't feel dark or dreary or anything really. It feels cartoonish if anything.Like I said, it might just not be the kind of game for me but I can't see any reason to keep playing it. The story never grabbed me, the characters blend together, the world is barren (apart from enemies), the combat gets repetitive and tedious and the atmosphere is lacking.

This game is even more buggier than the first one - still, years after first release.A few things were changed for the better - but unfortunately most changes made the game actually worse. content:
r 30, 2013
												TL:DR version:Good game. Not as good as the first game Shaodw Of Chernobyl as this one shows all the signs of a rushed game. But with some mods installed it's still very enjoyable.Long version:Prequel to the first STALKER game Shadow Of Chernobyl (SOC). Compared to the first one, which is a masterpiece, this game is short, buggier, and just generally a rushed game.They only made like 2 new maps while reusing all the textures and maps from SOC yet still manage to code it badly so it's full of bugs. Simply a lackluster effort.IMPORTANT TIP:DO NOT USE QUICK-SAVE QUICK-LOAD FUNCTION BUILT INTO THE GAME UNLESS YOU WANT TO HAVE CORRUPTED SAVEFILE THAT FORCE YOU TO START THE GAME OVER.So, in order to enjoy this, you will need community-made "mods", or patches since they fix bugs the developers are too lazy to fix.Sky Reclamation Project (SRP) (thank you Decane)http://www.gsc-game.com/index.php?t=community&s=forums&s_game_type=xr2&thm_page=1&thm_id=23248&sec_id=19This mod is a must as it fixes many game-crashing issues and it changes no gameplay so you can play the game how it's meant to be played.Clear Sky Complete (CS COMPLETE) (thank you Pavel)http://artistpavel.blogspot.ca/2010/01/mod-clear-sky-complete.htmlThe COMPLETE mods for the STALKER games are nice because they make the game look and sound better and play better. HOWEVER, even though this mod contains SRP, the SRP is an early version and does NOT include many fixes the most current version of SRP has. You WILL encounter game crashes and maybe even CORRUPT savefiles with this so use at your own risk.Now if you have some modding experience or some general knowledge of how script mods work then you can merge the up-to-date version of SRP with CS COMPLETE.  This is what I did so I can enjoy good graphcis+sound with no crashes.

content:
ber 2, 2015
												If I were going to be as fair with this review as this game was with me, it would be a one-sided argument of anger and frustration, lined with bits of compliments. However, I'm going to give this game something it never gave me: A ten second head start and a bandage when I really needed it,So for starters, let's be genuinely honest here; This is the most unique shooter experience I've ever dealt with. For starters, I've never played a game in which you fight armies of angry Russians armed with Iron Curtain weapons and even a few westernized weapons while I only have weapons with effective equivalence of Airsoft guns. Furthermore, every single person in the Zone is a better pitcher than anyone on any baseball team on earth. I mean, I have never been hit in the forehead with a grenade quite so often as I have been in in this game. I could cower behind a wall and say a prayer that I don't die and get hit with a grenade(Not the explosion, it literally bounces off my character) from half the combat platform away. Fast-Travel does exist, but it is quite literally the least convenient source of mobility since holding L2 to walk forward on a Playstation system. I believe I've made enough statements on how bad it may be there, but there are in fact positives. I am basing this review off my own personal experience, so certain aspects which may be good or bad for me may not be experienced by you personally. Now the start of the game is interesting enough, so long as you have a well enough understanding of the map and controls and how to utilize your PDA and the Artifact tracker. Seeing as I did not have a great understanding of these things, I went into the swamps and got half way to the second area of the game without completing the first two missions. So be warned, follow the yellow arrow and monitor the grey arrow as well. Now to the good aspects for realPros:+Vast area to explore; The Swamps are interesting to explore but only so long as you can avoid the anomalies.+Many different weapons and upgrades available+Random encounters with Mutants make this a horror experience as much as a shooter+Upgrades have weight to them, just as they have consequences +Buildings offer a lot of atmosphereCons:-Fast Travel can be the most expensive habit in the game-Most buildings have the most amazing atmosphere, but are too often empty of much worth exploring-Invisibility also means transparent/not able to be touched physically by weapons-T is for Tedium!-The ending sequence of the game is literally the best reason to Rage Quit-Game Breaking Bugs(Example: If you retrieve your gear before you go into Duty territory and talk to the commander, the option to talk to anyone is lost and the game can no longer be continued)-Pistols do not have iron sights but assault rifles do(Contrast to the older game, Shadow of Chernobyl)-Dude from Freedom Faction MAY TRY to sell you drugsOverall, it's not a great game. It's not a good game. It's barely within the respective zone for being an Okay game. I gave this game a legitimate try. I gave it serveral tries. As a matter of fact, on the last sequence of the game, I gave about sixty-four tries. However, if I were to count only the amount of times I restarted the campaign, it would be six. Three of those were due to glitches, three were due to Laptop changes and difficulty adjustments. My Final Rating for this game isA Red First-Aid Kit/10It's fine, but doesn't do much for you other than familiarize you with some controls and environments of the game, even if it isn't of a similar layout to the other games. It's good enough to hold you over until you can get the other two far superior versions of the game(Shadow of Chernobyl and Call of Pripyat). While it may quench your thirst for a Nuclear-Disaster based First-Person-Shooter, it is like comparing Resident Evil to the Resident Evil Remake; Only imagine that the Remake came out first. You can literally skip this installment.

content:
er 13, 2015
												The game isn't terrible, but it's not great either. The game devs were quite cruel when making this game.-Possible Spoiler Alert-Pros:-Repair system. This was much needed, as equipment tends to degrade quickly, which can make the game unnecessarily difficult.-Upgrades. Feeling of progression with the ability to improve your weaopns and armor.Cons:The game devs were really cruel when making this game.-The beginning of the game is pretty dumb. The bandits have all of the advantages against you (better accuracy, can spray accurately, tank more bullets than you), and you're constantly in 1v8 situations with little to no cover.-A powerful sniper rifle (VSS Vintorez) is available at the very beginning of the game. However, it is unusable without paying a hefty repair cost, and the ammunition it uses cannot be obtained until late in the game, at which this sniper is readily available. In short, it's just dead weight.-There's a machine gun emplacement that guns you down while you run for your life. This is impossible on the hardest difficulty, and even on the easiest difficulty, the machine gun will probably warrant a somewhat expensive repair.-At one point in the game, bandits steal all of your money. Adds insult to injury.-Bandits are total ♥♥♥♥♥, but only they can help you install the best armor upgrades. -Not many side quests.-The is too linear. I found myself passing through each area exactly once with little reason to backtrack. Unlike the other STALKER games, there's no central hub(s) where one can settle down and relax.Overall, not recommended unless you're a hardcore STALKER fan that wants bragging rights for playing all the games.

content:
y 30, 2016
												Stalker clear sky… A standalone addon to the Stalker game, which was very interesting from the side of new or fixed gameplay procedures and features, most noticeable from which are clan wars and system of weapon and gear upgrades. Also the feature with emissions where you in the middle of normal exploring all of sudden have to run fast to any shelter or die under not-so-clear-sky of the Zone. And new system of loot hunting, where you need special detector to find the Zone relics… And many other little things, most of them were invented and even implemented by the original game community.Being a hard fan, obsessed with the Stalker immerse world, I was able to made it through all Clear Sky quite fast, when it was just released. And I even felt the need to protect that title from blasphemous critics, who’s just not getting the point… But then I started the game for the second time, to really enjoy all its secrets and tight spots. And now I was puzzled with so many development decisions. Why they done it like this? Really, there should be some other way, there is no any logical base for this move. And that turn. And that was unnecessarily too… Now I feel only a shame for the developers, who ruined such interesting setting with totally unreasonable game plot. And, the worst thing is what all the bad stuff comes at player right away, just from the start! The first level in Swamps, after open wastes, forests and industrial compounds of the first game we need to follow the narrow passages... That's even worse than playing the second Crysis game right after the first one! A way worse. And after you manage through Swamps, the gameplot rushes you to go right on the army's outpost, with the outrageous machinegun (if you never played the game, just watch some vid's about "Clear sky military machinegun" on the youtube, there will be plenty). And if you managed to run out of that setup, you'll come into the Main Clear Sky Feature - the Clan Wars questline. Things finally starting to get interesting after Cordon... right until the moment you realise that all those clan wars are broken beyond repair. The major tip in the community about that quest line - don't do that!I can say the same about the whole Clear Sky in general. Unless you're a hardboiled Stalker veteran and going to download (or create) some mods for Clear Sky - don't even bother to start it, just get the Call of Pripyat instead, for much better experience.Me, I prefer the first STALKER game the most, even without mods. Even vanilla Shadow of Chernobyl gives you the biggest amount of adventure, and diversity of gaming experience. Both Clear Sky and Call of Pripyat are just two (of many) mods with the hope to improve some gameplay aspects. And Clear Sky is a lost hope. It done some good, but as a standalone game - it's a very frustrating experience, not worth of your time. Mark 5/10.

After a while you find out that mr. freaking bandit almost killed you with a pistol from 200 yards away, while yours is inaffective anywhere but point-blank.While in the old stalker you could use an object to hide from incoming fire, in here hiding does not make sense, when they spot you, they will fire upon you and will hit you. And they will spot you, even crouching and walking pace(slowest movement almost no sound) they will spot you in daylight or in the night as if they all wear NV goggles. Yes they will spot you and shoot around freaking corners or through objects...but that's oke FF. Well hell no it's not, cause once you come out of the swamps, the militairy is waiting for you. They'll ask you to go back, one more step and you are fodder. But you need to go that way cause you can't go another way. You cannot sneak upon or away from them. You need to go to the trader on your left and the only way to do it, is by running, they will sent a squad of 3 with body armor and very accurate akms...and one thing an akm is not... Good, you've survived by running...but those 3 militairy dudes followed you and are killing the stalkers in the village(3 of them) and you are next.One last thing, I was irritated in the old stalker by a guy in pripyat, come here stalker, my information...yeah that guy. Now they turned every freaking talking ape in the zone like him. Stand too close and they will spam you the same question over and over again....Save your money, use it to make a trip to the real chernobyl instead...I bet ya ,kissing the sacrofaag there is more fun then this game.

content:
ber 5, 2015
												I won't say this is a bad sequel, but this game has been very frustrating to finish.Compared to the first, there are some new useful features like fast travel (but very, very limited) and weapon/armor repairing and modifying.There is also a faction war system, that is cool and seems like the main feature of this new chapter, but it is (and should be, to avoid problems in game) totally avoidable.The plot is very trivial, unbalance is very annoying in some parts and bugs can oblige you to start again from a very old save state.The unbalancing, in particular, happened just approaching the last part of the main story. I had a very poor equipment and I was waiting to meet a shop to get better, but for like 3 areas, along the way, I met not a single shopper, only guys that could only repair my equipment (not even enhance it).So at some point I found myself in a long way without turning back until the end of the game (with no previous warning) with these crappy weapons and armor, and the game turned in a constant "loading and dying".In the end, the game feel a lot like its predecessor (intending it in a bad way, overall it feels just like playing again the first), but with some additional highs and lows that, depending on the individual game experience, can turn it good or bad like hell.Unfortunately, for me it has been a very bad and frustrating experience.

content:
y 7, 2016
												tl;dr Don't buy this because it's the cheapest stalker game. The original may cost twice as much, but with the Oblivion Lost mod, you can get the minimal added content from this game in the original. Clear Sky is simply SoC with a worse campaign, 3 extra maps, and a more annoying faction system. Simply patching the campaign/maps from this game into the original will provide a better game than this one.Faction Wars ruins the entire game.Having the military hate you wasn't enough, you'll constantly be met with stalkers who try to extort money from you, demand you defend their settlements which they make no attempt to defend themselves, and perma-agro if you walk the wrong places or refuse to allow them to extort you. Everyone wants you dead, and there's no ♥♥♥♥ing AK ammo anywhere. Pistols often jam twice in a row or on the first round of new magazines.

number of helpful: 10 of 25 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2014
												I loved Shadow of Chernobyl. It wasn't exactly as originally promised (the developers removed a handful of features), still, the game had a unique atmosphere that made it memorable. Then, not long after Clear Sky was released and everything I liked about SoC simply vanished.Clear Sky was an unnecessary sequel. The developer quickly made a sequel to cash in on a successful and famous game. They advertised it as a prequel story as the protagonist here follows the hero from the first game. But shouldn't you introduce new environments or areas in a sequel even if it is intended as a prequel story? You venture through the very same areas - even the map looks the same. At the beginning, you have a swamp-like are which is new, yes, but then you encounter the same places.The game uses the same engine but with DX10 features included. Still, you have a handful of bugs and the game can be very difficult at times - not only do you encounter respawning enemies but sometimes it is difficult to understand why it takes so many shots to finally eliminate someone.What happened to the super ending of the original game? Here, the final encounter in the centre of the zone seems rushed and non-creative. What happened to the different endings we had in SoC based on the gameplay-style we followed? Where are the new enemy types / gameplay elements / objects / weapons we expect from a sequel? Make no mistake: introducing new things is not a must but at least I would have expected to have the game rid of all the bugs it had in the original one.I remember the forest area being different. Instead of following the route next to it we finally ventured into it. It was dark and creepy and provided the necessary atmosphere. But this was the only thing in Clear Sky that I remember as good.You can pick this one up if you are a Stalker fan but I recommend downloading and installing the Complete Mod which rids the game of above-mentioned issues and introduces several new features.

number of helpful: 2 of 9 people (22%) found this review helpful
content:
er 21, 2014
												Wayne Campbell: Ah yes, it's a lot like "Star Trek: The Next Generation". In many ways it's superior but will never be as recognised as the original.In many ways that quote holds true with Clear Sky when you compare it to Shadow of Chernobyl, but Clear Sky is riddled with a lot of bugs and half baked concepts that, on the surface seem to be great improvements, but in reality, are poorly implemented and in a lot of cases, are almost game breaking, if not so. I don't make this assessment lightly and it's with a heavy heart that I do so... From start to finish, I wanted to enjoy this game, but it just never threw me a bone! Right down to the last boss, that glitched out and began to walk upon air, 50 meters above ground and take cover behind non-existent crates.*It was a pleasure to gather artefacts in the manner stated in the encyclopaedia from Shadow of Chernobyl, however it was often times frustrating to find artefacts that now had new abilities, some of which did the complete opposite of their SoC counterparts. *The upgrade system was nice, but needed a lot more work and an explanation in game of how the upgrade trees work.*The bandits at the Garbage can go eat ♥♥♥♥! Avoid them like the plague! And if you're like me and save up lots of money... Don't! Twice these no good ♥♥♥♥ers bled me dry and with no way to get it back... not even through bloodshed!*Exploration... What can I say? Shadow of Chernobyl... You look around... Find a nice gun... Or a suit or armour... With Clear Sky however, it's high risk for low to no reward! I know it's only early days in the Zone but at least reward exploration! God damn Scrooges!*GLITCHES!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Gotta love them! And 'them' there are many of... From the aforementioned floating final boss, to side quests the refuse to acknowledge the presence of the PDA in your inventory, to enemies that kill you in one hit if you happen to be in the air or jumping.*Faction wars... Actually the biggest problem here is your allies! Constantly pushing you out of cover and shooting you in the back, mindlessly trying to shoot an enemy! I lost count of the amount of times I was killed in the FW tutorial portion of the game... Shot in the back by a friendly shotgun! If you survive... You're expected to suck it up! ...And if you accidentally hit an idiot that walks in front of you, they get angry and gun you down... ♥♥♥♥ IT!(SIGHS) I know a lot of this sounds like nit picking, but hey! THIS IS THE GAME!!! This is the experience I had! ...And coming off of an enjoyable stint in the zone, in 'Shadow of Chernobyl', 'Clear Sky' was an utter disappointment and seemed more like a fart in an enclosed room than a clear blue sky of promise and in my opinion, will forever live in the 'Shadow of Chernobyl'... What? That didn't make sense? Get ♥♥♥♥ed!   XDDon't play this unless you're a die hard S.T.A.L.K.E.R, fan!

content:
, 2014
												One of the most broken games available. Even if you've got a load of extra cash lying around, I wouldn't recommend buying this game. The game seems great at first with wide-open areas and decent visuals but it all goes downhill from there. It seems the vast majority of the game is plagued with radiation that keeps you from exploring it, and all other areas are loaded with bandits and military goons. The biggest problem with the game are the loads of human enemies that litter the world turning it into a standard spray and pray shoot-out, but with a special catch: every single enemy is a bullet sponge that can absorb clip after clip, the only saving grace being that sometimes a headshot will kill them instantly. Other problems rise from certain parts of the game being a pain to get to because of broken hit-boxes or dozens of 'anomalies' being in the way that make traversing slow and mind-numbing. The tutorials also don't explain a whole lot, the UI is mediocre, and secondary quests are a pain to deal with because of a bad map and the many environmental blockages that will get in your way. It would be enjoyable to wander the expansive wastes, but sadly every five steps you take runs you into an irradiated field or an anomaly that will explode into a cloud of lightning and send you flying. Overall, a terrible game with basically no redeeming qualities.

content:
y 9, 2014
												Exploring the nuclear wasteland known as the "Zone" and delving into the heart of the Chernobyl reactor #4 to uncover artifacts and to discover the cause of the frequent radioactive emissions that go off more than ever before, all while battling the horrific mutated creatures caused by the second Chernobyl disaster and the bandits that want nothing but you dead and your stuff in their hands. It sounds like a lot of fun right? That is, until you actually play the game. The Optimization for this game is horrible, I can't even run it in directX 10 at a playable framerate (I can run BF4 on very high/ultra in a 64 player battle at 60+ FPS, as well as Planetside 2 with 200+ players). The NPCs are much too powerful (even on the easiest difficulty and I'm the type of person that always plays on the hardest difficulties), their grenades always seem to appear at your feet and their bullets always end up in your head. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy a challenge in combat but these enemies seem impossible to beat. The game has many bugs and quite a few random lag spikes that can last for more than 10 seconds.However, the game is not all bad. The ambience is fantastic and it really sets the dark mood of the Zone. The story is actually well written and gripping. The location also makes this game amazing as it takes place in the Chernobyl disaster zone (which I love), it is the perfect place for a game like this and lastly, the landscape is beautiful (I find that the abandoned buildings that nature has taken back are beautiful, that's just my view).This game has more cons than pros causing me to not recommend this. Stalker Clear Sky was too advanced for its time and had many issues. I would give this game a 65/100 simply due to the reasons I have stated. If you are looking for a game that takes place in a nuclear wasteland that has mutants and bandits I would recommend the Fallout series.

												On paper it sounded like a great game, a survival/horror shooter with some RPG elements, but it is hopelessly poorly implemented.  It is so buggy and unbalanced it is nigh on unplayable without modding (I tried Complete, Sky Reclamation Project, and Arsenal Overhaul), and even then it is not really great.  If you are a mind-reader you might do better, as it also has next to no tutorial, leaving it to the player to divine how things work, and what you need to do to complete mission objectives is not always made clear, so you are left to blunder around and try to figure it out, all the while under a rain of death from the infallible bullet-sponge AI.  Prepare to die over and over while you do that, which is weird for a survival game, the point of which is surely to NOT die.  I gave up on this one, I was just not having fun.

content:
ry 1, 2015
												Prequel to Shadows of Chernobyl and mostly same mechanics if not all with more things for better & worst.The artifacts' stats are now simplified and all except a very select few give off radiation. Those select few remove radiation so most of these ones are rare to find. Artifacts and anomalies can also now be detected via detectors so long as you're close enough to said artifacts and as you progress you can buy more improved detectors.The guns are all pretty much like the ones in SoC, you'll be lucky to get a headshot with a beginning gun. Clear Sky added a new upgrade and repair system that specific NPCs can provide for you. Repair is simply just to restore the condition of your weapons and armor whereas upgrades can vastly improve the actual weapons and armor you're using from guns decreasing in weight, armor having more specific protection stats, etc. However specific NPCs won't know how to upgrade certain guns or certain parts unless you go to another NPC or acquire a flash drive of the data for better improving equipment that that specific NPC can work with.Fast travel is now a thing where you can pay guides to take you to specific places of every explorable map. Prices vary on how far you're going.Clear Sky's got a new faction war system where a group from a specific faction can start to go to another faction's territory and try to take its place and if somehow you're friends with both sides you can help whichever side or let them go at it until one side loses so as you don't take a side. Unfortunately important characters can die from this so getting specific tasks may become impossible.One of the most irritating things about this game are the random emissions that can immediately kill you if you don't go inside an indicated shelter within the time limit. If you're the type who likes to loot and sell a lot of junk these can be a pain in the fanny for if you're too far from a shelter and you have a wide load you may have to sacrifice said loot just so you can get to the shelter in time. The emissions also take forever to actually happen (like, 1 or 2 minutes I didn't really check when it starts) so even if you're conveniently next to shelter you'll have to just sit inside and wait for the emission to end before going back to your usual S.T.A.L.K.E.R. ways.The spook factor, I thought, was gone and especially so since you don't really explore any labs. Going through the Red Forest though was cool at night but it wasn't really anything special, especially when dealing with annoying Bloodsuckers. It plays like Shadows of Chernobyl but much of what made the first game cool seemed to be gone and as a fan of the first game this was pretty disappointing. Even the two endings here weren't really interesting and you can probably skip this and just move on to Call of Pripyat.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
14, 2014
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky starts off with a terrible first impression. The main menu not only looks almost exactly like the first game's, but even the main menu music is the same. This isn't necessarily bad, but it's like a sick foreshadowing to the travesty that is this game.GRAPHICSVisually, this game is fairly good. However, it's nothing impressive. The first game allowed great immersion, even if you were only playing at the medium graphical settings. This game, however, fails to draw you into the setting, and I just groaned in contempt when I reached the end, where even the legendary and infamous Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant failed to stimulate my visual senses.GAMEPLAYThe game in terms of gameplay is definitely superior to the first entry. With more accurate weaponry and less shooting-through-walls glitches, I found myself not getting nearly as infuriated with the game as I did with the first. However, the survival/horror was absent entirely. The mutants were nearly nonexistent, whereas in the first game I was constantly on edge with the terror of the fantastic and varied enemies. But in this game, I found myself bored with fighting too many human enemies. Still, the mechanics are far superior than the first game, and I can give this props for that.MULTIPLAYERDon't play this mode. Please, for the love of all that is good and sane in this world, NEVER PLAY THIS MODE. Weapon balance is nearly nonexistent, maps and game modes are recycled from the first game. On top of that, you'll be hard pressed to find anyone playing this game's multiplayer. Stay clear of it.STORYThe game's story takes a massive hit. It is nothing more than a pale shadow in comparison to Shadow of Chernobyl. This game takes place one year before the events of the first game and tells the story of the zone and how Strelok came to be where he was in the first game. Sounds great on paper, but is overall disappointing. The game says multiple times that there are new areas to explore in the game because emissions have changed the radiation levels around the zone. This is complete and utter ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥T. There are a total of two new places to explore in the game. Otherwise, you visit literally EVERY SINGLE LOCATION FROM THE FIRST GAME. Actually, even less than that! The fact that I completed this game's story, while completing a few of the dull, uninspiring optional missions along the way, in a whopping 6 hours, proves that the developers were simply lazy with the game. You will shoot hundreds of humans all around the same places you've been to in the first game, and then sometimes shoot a mutant, repeat. Strelok is barely in the game at all, very little of the first game's supposed background history is given in this game, and it fails to inspire and enthrall like the first game. There was no mystery, horror, or intrigue throughout the course of this painfully short campaign, and it felt like a chore to go through.VERDICTThis game is $10 U.S. dollars not worth spending. This was a money-grabber after the success that was S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl. There was so much potential in this game that was simply wasted, and I was painfully reminded throughout the course of the game that I wasted money on a game that I will probably never play again. Make no mistake, this is one of the worst video games that I have ever played, a copy-and-paste of the original with less content and a worthless story. RATING: 5/10

content:
12, 2014
												I wanted to like this game as I had played the first STALKER game, however I found it has too many faults (and the first had it's fair share).1. Re-spawn bugs: NPCs that you just shot dead, and an area is clear, they look like they leap back from the dead or magically appear in front of you - making it impossible to take a base as your team NPCs never arrive, they seem to go wandering off in the wilderness.2. Persistence bugs and fails: leave an area and immediately return, and all the ground you gained has disappeared with your NPC bases taken back instantly (clock showing only minutes difference).3. Later in the game with improved weapons and armour, it seems that the low level weapons some NPCs have become more powerful than your own - such that a shotgun can take you out at 100+ metres. Whilst the fully upgraded sniper rifle won't even take an NPC out with a headshot, often requiring a full clip of 10+ shots to kill a NPC.4. None existent game levelling, comparing all game play levels and there was little to no difference between Novice to Veteran.5. Missions that appear and disappear within seconds, not even allowing you time to run to them even when only a few metres away.I have played many FPS, 3PS and RPG games for over a decade, always at highest difficulty. I am a fan of the series of Fallout, Crysis, CoD, Battlefield, Far Cry, Skyrim, Dragonage, Mass Effect etc etc. But this one unfortunately is not going in that list, like I said I really did want to like it, but the above eventually wore me down, I don't want to finish it... so I really can't recommend it - follwing this review it's being uninstalled.

content:
y 12, 2013
												A so-so prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl that re-uses most of the SoC assets to flesh out the original story. Plays a lot better when you ignore the main 'quest' and go wandering. The new faction wars feature would have been the saving grace of the title if it wasn't quite so buggy and had a touch more depth to it.It's nice to wrap yourself in the Stalker atmosphere again but overall the game feels too much like a simple (and flawed) expansion rather than a stand-alone game.

number of helpful: 2 of 11 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2014
												I'm a big STALKER fan and one of my friends, who is a much larger fan of everything related to the series, told me to stay away from Clear Sky. I figured that even something vaguely Stalkery would be still pretty good because Pripyrat and the original were very enjoyable, but I after playing through Clear Sky I see why people say stay away. 1. Very short 2. Very linear with exploration discouraged 3. Less focus on monsters/mutants and more on killing hundreds of human enemies4. Ending is terrible5. You have very few, if any, choices beyond which faction to fight for6. Faction Wars idea feels like it is barely fleshed out 7. Upgrade system and a few other things tied to the factions are not fun8. Little sense of what either of the other two Stalkers are all about (weird ♥♥♥♥, exploration, mutants and being a Stalker)9. Only one ending as far as I can tell10. Several repetitive sections were you just kill waves after waves of human enemiesLet me explain some of those a little more. The game is a bit short, especially comapred to the other two. My record says 20 hours, but 3-4 hours of that are idle-time when I left it on and the rest was doing absolutely everything I could in terms of side missons/faction wars and trying to explore areas that didn't want to explored. I imagine you could easily run though it (without trying hard) in less than 10 hours. The entire feeling of world is almost erased from what was created in the original game (and Pripyrat even though that came after this one). You can only find things if they are randomly located by this guy back at the original base that randomly gives you locations of stashes, or if you buy tips from people for stashes. If you happen to find that stash on your own without doing either of those things then nothing will be in it, hence discouraging exploration. A lot of the areas are also pretty closed off or empty besides human enemies, which kind of give tiers of loot depending on where you are in the games story. All of this might be fine if the story was good, it isn't because it goes against the original's story and just kind of sucks all around, or if the Faction War system was actually good. The Faction War system, which is a big focus of the game and one of the main things going on all the time (also one of the main reasons there is less focus on mutants and exploration) is a really shallow offering. You have no real impact on anything and only if you get a mission to take an area will the A.I. faction you are fighting for actually go and capture it. They give you a lot of good rewards for doing missions and taking over areas, but it is all very temporary and the whole system isn't the slightest bit dynamic. The A.I. rarely does anything on their own, they have no ambition, and even when you do the "big mission" that is supposed to supress an enemy faction the area is only captured for 15 minutes at most. You cannot command any squads, request reinforcements if you take somewhere on your own, or really interact with your faction at all beyond their main bases, which just offer shops. It was very disappointing to experience because it could have been something much more complex, dynamic and enjoyable. Somewhere in all of this is an actual STALKER game with great environments, horrifying enemies, a great upgrade system and so much more, but I whole heartedly recommend playing Pripyrat instead even if you have already beaten it before and you are just looking for another go at this wonderful world.

content:
er 31, 2013
 Originally posted on June 3, 2009 I loved STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl. It wasn't perfect, but it was a really exciting game. However, after playing STALKER: Clear Sky for over 25 hours, I am unable to continue. The game is broken. Allow me to explain.Graphically speaking, Clear Sky is a huge step up from SOC. It uses some of the most advanced shadows I've seen in a game, and the day and night cycle is incredibly immersive. All of the haunting art design and character modeling for the first game is there, but with improved models. However, the game is also so poorly optimized that it cannot run DirectX11 shadows without becoming a slide show, and continues to give me burst of awful (5-10 fps) lag on my rig. And trust me, my rig is not the problem. I've confirmed that this problem is widespread among many gamers, and is not just isolated to me.The sound in the game is exceptional, of course. Weather, ambient noise, howls, fire crackling, gunshots, etc, all really help to immerse you in the zone. I have no complaint's about the sound design.If the lag was the only issue, I would probably have finished this game lag and all. I certainly tried to. Of course I saw where it was headed, but the thrill *spoiler* of putting Strelok in the place we find him in SOC drove me onward. *spoiler* However, the combat mechanics, which were really great in the first game, especially the gunplay, are broken in this game.Yes, the AI is more intelligent than in SOC; it uses cover, flanks you, and throws grenades. However, enemies tend to throw grenades in bursts at your EXACT position, and STALKER is NOT a movement friendly game. It feels incredibly unbalanced as one grenade will hurt you even if you sprint away from it immediately, and you will lose your cover. Multiple grenades almost always mean death.The ballistics model in this game is a big disappointment in comparison to the first. All types of guns are WILDLY inaccurate at ranges above 50 feet, unless they are absolutely tricked out with accuracy upgrades. With a standard AK 74 or Abakan, you can't hit a damn thing at 100m, and are almost always forced to use assault rifles as if they were SMGs (grenade spamming and charging in headlong). I had to spend a good 15000 rubles on my TRS 301 just to get it to perform like it did un-modded in the original game. The AI, of course has none of these accuracy issues, and can happily hit you at 100m plus with any gun in the game, including the MAKAROV!While the faction wars system is interesting, it's makes the zone feel too crowded, and not nearly as spooky or desolate as in the first game. In addition, whenever you conquer new territory, it takes the AI forever to send backup, which usually consists of 1-3 men to help you fend off the multiple counterattacks the enemy sends, usually consisting of 10 plus total men. You may have total numerical superiority, but if 300 of your best equipped stalkers are sitting in your base territory, you have a problem. This is supposed to be a war, not a one man take down border skirmish.In conclusion, I'm not wild about the new weapon upgrade system, but I could see it working in a future title, and i love being able to repair my gear, finally. The new detector and revamped anomaly system is good, and the new graphics and AI are great for the most part. Now fix the balance, lag, gameplay issues, performance, and bring back the spookiness, and cut out the generic side quests, and we'll have a great game.Here's to Call of Pripyat..... *sigh*

												Meh. Buggy, bland world, uninteresting npc's and quests, half the guns  jam every other clip and like to shoot around people but never at them, you're sprinting back across the map most of the time to turn in a quest you finished an hour ago for a sub-par reward, and it has a *ridiculous* difficulty setting that eventually ruins the game outright (ridiculous because there is a function in the game programming that makes your bullets have a 40%-70% chance to literally disappear out of the air depending on what difficulty you chose). Later in the game, this will make it appear as tho one enemy is eating 2 entire clips right in their face before going down. Game's definitely fun if you like looking at a loading screens - the quicksave and quickload keys are the only useful things in your arsenal the whole time. Overall, just feels like a lot of areas in the game didn't get the attention or time they sorely needed. Don't spend your money on this without doing some in-depth review hunting first. In my opinion, there are plenty of other much better options for the $10 - $20 price range: any Fallout, Far Cry, Borderlands, Deus Ex games - heck, I could go on, and that's just others I've played recently. Play those games if you want a better rpg-shooter hybrid, not STALKER Clear Sky.

content:
er 16, 2012
												S.T.A.L.K.E.R Clear Sky is the follow up to the sleeper hit Shadow of Chernobyl, a game that somehow managed to overcome it's many flaws and limitations and be a great game. Clear Sky brings along many new additions and upgrades, particularly in the graphics department. And while all of this sounds great on paper the only thing it manges to accomplish is driving home the point that there are no good or bad ideas, only good and bad executions.The core gameplay remains the same, you are a "Stalker", a traveler in the cordoned off wasteland that surrounds Chernobyl. An area filled with radiation, mutated monsters and dangerous anomalies. Not to mention the rather high population of other stalkers and residents of "The Zone" that are also collecting the rare artifacts spawned by the anomalies and the various factions that each try to impose their own ideals on the zone and it's inhabitants.The faction system is one of the major new features of Clear Sky. They will send off groups of stalkers on their own attempting to secure various points of importance throughout the game world and if you are allied with them you will often be asked to participate in various offensive and defensive actions as mini-missions. This makes the world seem much more alive and as there are not only constant movement around the maps but it's also directed movement, everybody trying to gain the upper hand.The second big addition is the increased character customization. Your weapons and armor have many options that allow you to increase their potential in various ways. Many of the upgrades are exclusive as well so instead of making a super gun you have to specialize your weapons and armor. The developers have listened to the community as well and another part of this is the increased rarity of artifacts and the increased difficulty in collection them which is a very welcome addition.The unfortunate truth however is that both these additions come in a heavily flawed state and especially the faction system will lead to many hours of frustration. The game still has that "raw" feeling, despite the improved graphics, and where in Shadow of Chernobyl this was mostly forgivable the increased problems with Clear Sky makes it come out at you much more.Clear Sky is a unfortunate sequel that hasn't quite grown enough since Shadow of Chernobyl. It still has all of the problems that Shadow of Chernobyl and adds several of it's own which leads to a sequel that is less than it's predecessor.
